pros:
-Although not corporate policy,  most supervisors are supportive of flexible scheduling and family responsibilities 
-Inspiring work 
-Great retirement benefits 
-Excellent speakers (i.e., brown bags) to learn about health areas
-Small enough organization that you feel your work and output really matters 
-Inspiring CEO 
-Great communications staff and some other units stand out too, but there is more mediocrity here than I am used
cons:
-Open secret that 80% of Executive Team and senior management have overstayed and are not strong, collaborative leaders. But, there is no accountability by CEO (despite being so inspiring!) which results in poor morale. 
-Office lay out is very badly designed and staff have little privacy OR open space 
-Financial systems are badly designed for tracking expenses according to budget.  
-Strong early and mid-career staff are hampered by poor staffing decisions, poor senior management, and  no clear promotions policy. These staff are paid very little compared to others, do most of the work, and are easily taken advantage of.  Promotions are feasible, but take a lot of time and a lot of support to obtain (and not based on high performance ). 
-Endemic lack of responsiveness to staff ideas for improving systems or efficiencies

review_title: Flexible NGO with opportunities to grow
job_title: Finance Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
I enjoyed the flexibility at IntraHealth.  This is a great place to work for self-starters.  There are guidelines and protocols in placed but they leave enough space for you to expand into other areas of interest.  
The organization is full of dedicated staff, who are for the most part genuinely warm and friendly and able to accomplish their work successfully.  
The projects that IntraHealth implements are both purposeful and impactful.  
I found the salary and benefits competitive.
cons:
The CFO is unstable.  One day you're his best friend and the next day he is talking about you behind your back and telling his audience not to say anything.  I've rarely met such an unsavory and unscrupulous individual.  As long as you can distance yourself from him, you'll generally be surrounded by wonderful colleagues.  
There are periods in which the workload is unbalanced.  During proposals for instance, you should expect weekend work.  This isn't unreasonable in my opinion as that is the nature of the job and is the result of unrealistic turnaround times established by funders.  
As with any organization funded by the government, there are ebbs and flows.  During the low periods, expect a tense environment and a small exodus of staff.

job_title: Strategic Information Manager in Juba, Baḩr al Jabal
pros: its best for the researcher
cons: Great for the uninformed employee

job_title: Pricing Analyst in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The culture is very welcoming here
cons: Smaller company so not as much room for growth

pros:
There are SOME lovely people at the org. It's also in a great location. Other than that, this org doesn't have much going for it. Benefits were also good. 

Other pros, learning what you will NOT accept in a work environment.
cons:
IH claims to be an org of "innovation" but, I couldn't imagine a more antithetical word to describe it. For an organization that holds itself to be the leader in HUMAN RESOURCES for health, it sponsors little to no development for its own employees. We had plenty of tools and resources expertly developed to help field clinical staff but none of which were given the time or resources to be applied to our own staff. The employee development technique at HQ is "sink or swim". Throw as many tasks at the new person with no structure or support and see if they fail. If they fail, replace and exploit the next.  From day 1 I was greeted by the utter misery of the current staff, who advised that the only way to move up was to "not say no to anyone".
The senior management and executive board are completely out of touch and closed off to any and all suggestion. The only way to "survive" the chopping block in this organization is to pander to the antiquated and misguided executive team. Once you have ego-stroked your way to the top, there is also no guarantee you will be safe. Backstabbing can occur at any moment.

This organization has no interest in doing good for humanity. Do not be fooled.

job_title: Training Capacity Building Officer in Dhaka
pros: Staff Friendly, Supportive Supervision, Learning Environment, Ambitious, Positive
cons: Nothing to mention as negative experience

pros: It is an organization that truly takes care of their employees
cons: Only that it is contract based

job_title: Senior Health Information Systems Specialist in Kinshasa
pros: Good place to expand ones career
cons: Low salary especially for African regions

review_title: Mission-driven, meaningful employment with a good work-life balance
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: I have been at IntraHealth International close to 10 years and have been there through some of our best years and more difficult years. I wake up inspired to go to work because I love our mission of supporting health workers and healthy systems globally. In my experience, it is a collegial environment and most of my coworkers are kind and supportive. It is fun and energizing to work with staff from all over the world.  In the past I have less supportive supervisors, but now I have a wonderful relationship with my boss who has invested in me to grow professionally and allowed me to pitch ideas to improve the way we do business. I enjoy being challenged to grow technically and have gained many new skills through being allowed to go after new opportunities. I do think our organization does a good job elevating the voices and leadership in our country offices rather than being too top-down from the headquarters office.
cons: We are trying to adapt in a quickly changing environment and making great strides, but I hope we can continue to do so faster.

pros: Overall, a great place to work. It's in the middle of a lot of changes, but my colleagues are hardworking and the organization does important work. I feel good about my contributions and have had opportunities to stretch and grow here. Great benefits.
cons: We're in the middle of a leadership change combined with volatility in our field of global health in general. So, it's not a good fit for someone who needs lots of stability right now. Things are changing & quickly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Doing strong work in the field. 

Good retirement benefits and vacation time. 

Generally friendly and passionate colleagues (with some clear exceptions, unfortunately).
cons:
Ridiculous levels of inequality among employees. There are clear “favorites.” Even within the same department, policies like remote work are unevenly enforced. 

Little to no professional development. No opportunities for growth within the organization. Don’t come here expecting to work your way up. Numerous vacancies due to inability to retain entry and mid- level staff. 

An organization that promotes maternal health and does not offer parental/maternity leave for staff. 

Extremely top-heavy. Many senior members have overstayed and are no longer effective, leaving lower level staff to pick up their slack. 

Some employees are passive-aggressive, attitudes left unchecked by management. It’s counter-productive and leads to low morale. We’re all on the same team, but it often doesn’t feel like it.

job_title: Finance And Operations in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The executive team is steadily confronting business practices that have not served the organization well. New VPs of Finance and Operations, HR, Technical Excellence, and recruitment of VP of Programs underway.  New leaders have raised the bar, infusing the organization with vision and integrity. Plenty of opportunity in my department for those who are open to learning and go above and beyond.
cons: Still some dead weight and resistance to change by certain departments, but the pendulum has swung significantly in the right direction in the last year. Fiscal year goal setting is out of sync with best business practices.

review_title: Great place to start your career
job_title: Program Specialist in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great respect for life/work balance, friendly people, and a really tangible commitment to making a difference in the lives of people in the countries in which IH works.
cons: The organization has a lot of very senior people and a lot of junior ones - very few in the middle. It is very difficult to advance your career past the specialist/officer level. Competency in senior management varies widely, which directly affects whether you will be able to advance.

review_title: Mission driven NGO learning to be a business.
pros:
Like many USG funded NGOs, this company has a history as a small, mission driven organization and a big vision for the future. In a rapidly changing environment, IntraHealth is striving to "grown-up" to become a global leader and learning that hard choices and bold action is part of the package. Recent years have yielded good progress and they are poised for a vibrant future in tough times. A few points on working here:
- Inspirational CEO
- Mission and field programs
- Opportunities to contribute 
- Opportunities to shine
- Opportunities to create something
cons: Still in transition, in need of more management emphasis, career paths and difficult choices for human capital investments. NC HQ is a bit removed from the DC development scene.

review_title: Don't be fooled by the "mission" - it's politics as usual.
pros: The benefits package is exeptional - a 6% employer contribution and up to 4% match of your contribution too. There are usually a variety of opportunities to get involved in work that excites you, even if it isn't technically in your job description. The people are generally a very nice group, and the IT team is amazing - competent and friendly.
cons: It is very difficult to get a promotion or raise (it can take over a year to get the raise your manager approves), and the policies and procedures are easily overwritten by personal agendas. Most of the jobs are essentially dead-ends, and if you want to build your career, you will have to leave the organization. Turnover and low morale is common.

review_title: Not perfect but wouldn't trade it
pros:
IntraHealth has a great mission, lots of dedicated people, and almost everyone I've worked with there believes strongly in improving health care around the world. I'm sure there are some bad apples here & there, but overall, my colleagues keep me motivated.

IntraHealth has the spirit of a small nonprofit, has a great benefit package & 401k match, pretty generous salaries, and generally speaking seems to prioritize its programs over its headquarters (depending on where you sit, this could be positive or negative).

The work is meaningful and you're surrounded by people who care about each other and the work. I've found my colleagues are helpful & collaborative.

Career paths are improving. It used to be hard to formalize growth in your job particularly for early career professionals.

There's considerable flexibility, e.g. work from home arrangements, etc., in most departments.
cons:
IntraHealth has an extremely meeting-intensive culture; it can be hard to find work time to get your actual work done; and in some roles/departments, work-life balance can be elusive. 

Depending on your supervisor, you need to be skilled at setting boundaries and prioritizing; otherwise good work is rewarded with getting much more to do thrust upon you.

The organization has tried on different personalities over the years--going from a very organic, touchy feely approach all the way to trying to be super/too corporate lately. Probably a result of growing pains and different executive influences along the way. I wish it could find a happy medium.

Office space is not fairly or well designed....you either get a pretty great office or you're stuck in these fairly open & loud spaces in small desks.

In the past, I'd say HR policies haven't been very transparent. Cautiously optimistic that that is changing. There is new leadership in HR.

review_title: Great perks but no work life balance
job_title: Project Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Opportunity to travel or be apart of inspiring and rewarding work. Opportunity to build lifelong relationships.
cons: The work practically owns your life. It's nearly impossible to leave work at the office and not have to respond to stay on top of emails after hours. I'm pretty certain this was the case for most everyone. There is not much job security as work is always dependent on winning contracts that last on average of 1-2 years.

job_title: Program Officer in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The organization is doing good work in general. It offers good benefits, option to work from home occasionally, travel opportunities, external training opportunities, some good and smart people who actually care about what they do, great location.
cons: Not responsive to suggestions, not open to change or new ideas, some managers don't take responsibility to improve the old ways, but like to blame their team members, hard work isn't always rewarded unless it's by one of their favorites, unnecessary constant travels by some senior managers, the roles and responsibilities (especially between Programs and Finance) are not clear or logical. The room for professional growth within the organization is very limited.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great colleagues. Well-intentioned and talented staff, many of whom are demotivated by behaviors of executive team focused on conferences rather then the quality of programs.  Staff become apathetic after time.
cons: Out of touch leadership, especially the CEO.  Other members of the executive team seem to be complacent - perhaps they want to keep their jobs and it is best not to rock the boat. Staff turnover is constant and high among top performers; yet senior management will not look at this closely to determine why and make needed changes.

pros: Great (and improving) benefits, responsive to suggestions, open to change and innovation, hard work is rewarded, flexible schedule, very smart and dedicated colleagues. The executive team is continually trying to make improvements to workflow, systems, benefits, policies, and the overall organizational structure.  ET is also looking towards the future and trying to increase/maintain funding so IH can continue to fulfill it's mission.
cons: Policy changes can  take a while to implement, decisions are not always transparent. Some staff who are not pulling their weight remain employed.

review_title: Once you are in headquarters, you will wish you had listened to the reviews
job_title: Staff Member in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Small organization.  You get to know most everyone who works there.  Good people work at the organization.  Good retirement plan and benefits.  Good location.
cons:
IntraHealth is an organization in disarray.  The President/CEO has been absent for years and does not provide leadership or management.  He is disengaged in the work and demotivates staff,  when he is around.   He travels a lot, but no one sees any tangible results from the travel.

In general, the organization lacks direction, vibrancy and energy.  For most staff, it is a paycheck.  The mood in the office is pretty low.  It is a real shame because there are good people working in the organization.  With better leadership and direction, the organization could thrive.

Do not work here if you are a person of color.  In the Program/MER team almost no person of color has remained beyond one year—except the African Directors.  There are always ''performance issues.''    Those who work in operations lack opportunity to grow and develop as they are passed by for promotions.  People of color are the first to be laid off.  Women of color suffer in the organization.  Management knows the problems but has taken no action.  

In general, there is little room for growth and development in IntraHealth.    

The culture is full of favoritism.  Some staff have stayed way too long, do not pull their weight and management will not move these people out of the organization.  The organization is top heavy with too many directors—many  were given positions in exchange for a favor done for the President.  At times, these have not been real jobs.  One person was a director of a department with no staff for years.  One year 25% of the staff got promotions in name only as they were considered a flight risk.  Management did not understand the message sent to the remainder of the staff and there has been steady departures since.    However, since a new HR head arrived, there has been improvement in this area.

pros: Openness with information, Dress code is casual and comfortable, Management is open to receiving feedback on ideas for growth.  Company uses participatory model when making decisions to involve all staff and increase buy-in.  Opportunity to travel internationally.
cons: USAID is primary funder of the organization, so because of the reporting structure and funding mechanism, limitations are placed throughout the organization.  I.e. inability to cater monitoring and evaluation to thoroughly assessing impact and outcomes of programs because USAID funding requires numbers driven reporting.

pros:
Pretty good benefits package including, retrirement. 
SOME really kind and talented thinkers. 
Approachable CEO. 
SwitchPoint! 
Great mission, great work in the field, great teams in the field.
cons:
Transparency is poor organizationally and especially within departments. There is clear racial bias and unfortunately the people who don't benefit from this have zero power. There are clear favorites within departments fostering poor professional growth, demoralization, etc. Opportunities are unevenly and unequally distributed (seemingly intentional).

The organization relies on the same people for certain tasks , finding themselves overburdened during high volume times and when there is "no capacity" left. I cannot count how many times I've heard we do not have th capacity to do x, y, z, yet there is nothing being done about it. Instead, management would rather bad-mouth the people who have the potential but possibly haven't had the opportunity to even try or learn something new by outwardly saying how "useless" someone is. Apparently, there are a lot of "useless" people at IntraHealth. 

SOME in higher powered positions are complicit, allowing bad behavior. The organization has a really hardtime facing hard truths. This makes it difficult to find a colleague who can advocate for you. When the bullies ARE your team, it's even more difficult to advance. 

Poor people mangement and poor delegation of tasks. 

Pay scale seems off (especially for people of color). Offer insultingly low salaries upon hire and do not make room for negotiation. This is with prior experience, higher education, etc. Contributes to the wage gap in this country.

review_title: Nonprofit with great intentions and drive but sometimes lacks adequate organizational support to "get there"
job_title: Program Officer in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great benefits, fulfilling purpose, some staff are incredible to work with, strong and client/employee-centered IT dept.
cons: Some staff are miserable to work with; a little too much political influence trickles down from primary funder; too much lip service with regards to suggested improvements from employees

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The executive team is a mess, but there are some wonderful people working at IntraHealth.  I would recommend it if you are looking to cut your teeth in international development but use the experience as a stepping stone to a more professional organization with a true focus on international development rather than self-promotion.
cons: There is way too much focus on senior management attending conferences and on the annual SwitchPoint event rather than on programs and program impact. The executive team expects total loyalty from staff; yet, they keep demonstrating the ease with which they marginalize and/or fire long-term previously beloved staff leaving remaining staff wondering who is next to go.

review_title: Huge issues with senior management - CEO & VP level
pros: Great mission, many kind hearted people, good salaries and benefits
cons: CEO and VPs are very insular, have worked together for too long and have little to no outside experience beyond IntraHealth.  CFO is newer but there are many problems with how he speaks to people and about people.  Serious issues to be addressed.

pros: Most people at IntraHealth seem to really believe in its mission. The organization respects work-life balance, and is making a strong effort to develop the leadership potential in people at all levels. I felt I could discuss issues of concern with anyone, all the way up to the CEO.
cons: The cons aren't so much with IntraHealth itself as with working in for an NGO in general. Most NGOs live and die by the project cycle. That can make for a bumpy career ride.

pros: Great  place to work and build experience ,especially for recent grads. Mission driven and dedicated to changing lives in developing countries
cons: Constrained by a limited scope of technical areas and expertise. This is hampering growth and expansion in an increasingly competitive environment.

review_title: Positive work environment, but still bureaucratic
pros: Organization is mission-driven and people care about public health. Co-workers are respectful and positive. Managers seemed open to new ideas, and I felt like my voice was heard.
cons: Actual impact of work was unclear; lots of effort spent trying to get the next grant (though this is true for many NGOs).

pros: Its a great organisation providing Techncial assistance to the Health sector in devloping nations. Expertise in various Heralth related aspects be it clinical or public Health.
cons: All the organisatinal control are vested at its headquarters in North carolina which some what limits the functions. Sometimes sounds very odd as more flexibility is required.

pros:
Very nice place to work.
Central downtown DC location and Metro right across the street from the job
cons: Driving to works is not ideal for this job

review_title: organizer, trainer, conducted supportive supervision in the mother support group sites

cons: stake holders challenges during implementation.

pros: Provided opportunity to network and learn the landscape
